Headline.Para: To Incorporate or Not: That Is the Question

LeadPara.Para: On the Hulu television series ''Runaways,'' James Yaegashi plays a powerful dark wizard capable of unleashing a black hole of bats and teleporting aliens back to their planetoids. But when it came to his taxes this year, Mr. Yaegashi needed some help.
Because of the new tax law, thousands of New York City actors like Mr. Yaegashi have been streaming into their accountants' offices, eager to incorporate in order to save money.

TailParas.Para: ''It's been nonstop -- everyone wants advice,'' said Craig Manzino, an accountant who specializes in the entertainment industry and represents about 1,000 actors and actresses. He and his associates at Prager Metis CPAs have been working overtime fielding queries and setting up S-corps. Among fellow accountants, Mr. Manzino says the new Republican tax law is known as ''The Full Employment Act for Accountants.''
Since January, Mr. Manzino has created 12 new corporations among his clients; he expects to incorporate at least twice as many clients as usual by the end of the year. ''Maybe quadruple,'' he said.

Though the tax rate has dropped by 3 percent and the standard deduction has doubled, people who work in creative industries can no longer deduct the big expenses that contribute to their success. According to the new tax law, expenses like buying scripts for auditions, taking acting classes and hiring a voice coach are no longer deductible. ''Actors are spending 20 to 30 percent of their income just to generate jobs,'' said Mr. Manzino. ''If you're a gym trainer or a lawyer or work for the Yankees, you don't have to worry about expenses like that.''

Adam Donshik, an actor who appeared in shows like ''House of Cards,'' decided to form his own entity in December. For him, deducting head shots, haircuts, clothing, and travel expenses used to be the norm. ''Those are things that might seem mundane,'' said Mr. Donshik, who lives in Montclair, N.J., and whose career spans everything from Mountain Dew commercials to Shakespeare. ''But for an actor making a living wage, it was the only way you could survive.''

By incorporating, those lost expenses can be offset, though incorporating carries some costs of its own. The initial filing fees may cost around $1,000. But then there are costs that the newly incorporated actor must pay: Medicare, social security, corporate taxes. Add in the bookkeeping and accounting costs, and in the end it could cost as much as $20,000.
Also, if you're incorporated, you can no longer receive unemployment if you're out of work.

''We run the calculus, and ask if we can save you enough money,'' said Mr. Manzino. Each case is different, depending on whether you're married or single, rent or own and, most important, how much money you make. Looking at three different clients working on the same show and earning the same salaries, Mr. Manzino recommended that only one of them incorporate. It wasn't worth it for the other two.

His general rule of thumb is that performers making over $200,000 -- already a rare accomplishment, as the median annual salary among union film and television actors is around $38,000 -- should seriously think about incorporating. This easily knocks most actors with support jobs out of the equation, as income can't include money earned working at Starbucks or as a temp at a law firm -- corporations themselves through which that money flows.

For most working New York actors, earning incorporation-level money usually means lucrative commercial work or a steady gig on a television series -- like the one Mr. Yaegashi landed last year on '' Runaways.'' The idea of incorporating was one that had always floated among actors he's known, but it got some extra buzz once the new tax code was passed in December.

''I knew a lot of friends who had incorporated and so I talked to them,'' said Mr. Yaegashi, who lives in Brooklyn. ''But then I went to Craig and talked to him about the nitty gritty. Then finally pulled the trigger.'' Last month, Mr. Yaegashi incorporated. ''But I'm fully aware that in a year or two, things may look very different.''

Working a show often means leaving New York, which racks up tens of thousands of dollars in costs like a second apartment rental, food expenses and car rentals, which all comes out of the actor's pocket. ''I have a family here in New York,'' said Mr. Yaegashi. ''So when I leave town to work in L.A., I'm paying for two households. It adds up, and it hurts.''

Another way accountants have helped their creative clients is to encourage them to put money in retirement plans. ''Putting $54,000 in a 401(k) could save you $25,000 in taxes,'' said Mr. Manzino. ''But not everyone can afford to put that much away.''

One of the pitfalls of advising clients for the coming year is that the Internal Revenue Service has not yet issued its guidelines on interpreting the new law. ''This is language written by politicians Christmas week, and so there are all kinds of snags,'' said Mr. Manzino. The I.R.S. advice is not going to be out until June 30.
''So we're left guessing,'' he said. Establishing a corporation can be done at any time during the tax year, but will apply only to income made while incorporated.

Even more daunting -- and nearly impossible -- is trying to figure out if an actor's income will remain at the same level as the previous year to offset the costs of incorporating. ''In this business, you don't take anything for granted,'' said Mr. Yaegashi. ''You learn to surf the waves and try not to drown.''
The Particulars
Project Actors incorporating under the new tax law
Driving force Entertainment industry accountants
In the works Since passage of the so-called Tax Cuts and Jobs Act on Dec. 20
Cost Anywhere from $1,000 to more than $20,000
